item.description:
From the publisher:
Do you like singing? What about the singing games? Random Sopanen (artist) - Play and Sing is a fun children's game in which you qualify Satu Sopanen colorful and joyous songs of the world. Do you recognize the right words of the song? Do you know how to perform fun tasks properly? In this game, the main issue is having fun with music! Fairy-tale songs from Sopanen has characters to act a like and there are different music programs. Sing and act with Random children's favorite performers and act out the musical instruments in air. Includes CD's, with 18 pieces of previously unreleased songs, and Satu Sopaselta Tuttiorkesterilta.
Game idea is to collect the full piano (made from puzzle pieces, 6 of them). Each player in his/her turn takes a card (from 4 different categories) and acts accordingly. You either have to act the singer (moving mouth to the words), make instruments in the air, sing along with the music making the sound of the animal you drew with the card or be part of the duet. You are scored by other players, basically if they are happy with the performance and collect a piece. If not happy, you may take another card and try again. If still not happy, you pass and wait for the next turn.
Game is over when piano is completed.

The game was played much like Trivial Pursuit, running in a circular motion with the players collecting coloured counters upon answering various questions or completing a particular task. The colour coding defined which question would be asked and the reward for a right answer was one of the tokens. A completed set of tokens meant the player could then progress into the center circle and complete the game.

Object of the game is being the first team to reach the destination square, betting on issues and events, and
course by providing the correct answer.

Players/teams move on the game board and if they reach on a certain squares, the other team draws a card, reads the topic aloud and asked the current team to bet on this theme 1-3 credit. Then they answer and if it is correct they win the bet if incorrect they lose credtis and move their pawns back.

Team who first arrives to the destination square must answer the last question to win the game.

This is a light war game based on two teams of kids facing off in a game of capture the flag. Their weapon of choice: Pine Cones. In this simultaneous action selection game, out think your opponents by choosing the best strategy. Each turn, you get to choose two actions in secret and then they are resolved in player order. You can move, gather pine cones, throw pine cones, or rest to recover damage.

Do you rush for the flag, or gather an armful of pine cones before you advance? Do you attack from a safe distance or close in for the knockout blow? There is no player elimination, but any player taking too much damage misses turns until he's rested enough to return to the game.

The World's Greatest Hockey Game is a simulation hockey game based on player performance from the previous year.

The player cards are broken down on a percentage basis, reflecting how often a particular player shot the puck, forced a face-off, took a penalty, threw an interception or passed. Separate sections on the cards reflect a player on a powerplay or playing shorthanded.

Delayed penalties and shooting off the rebound were also factored in by special rules reflecting these aspects.

One additional detail regarding TWGHG should be noted. In this game, the players for each team in a given season are those who were set to appear on opening day for the current year. This differs from hockey game systems such as Strat-O-Matic or Statis Pro, where card sets were published only after a season was completed. TWGHG was intended for players who wanted to use the opening day rosters and play out a season as it was progressing.

item.description:
The Metre Litre Gram Game is the fun way to learn metric.

The game consists of a playing board, six player tokens, two dice, five decks of cards (metre, litre, gram, chance, and exam), a rule sheet and a sheet that explains the metric system.

The path on the board is in the shape of the letter m, which stands for metre. The left leg has metre questions, the middle section has litre and temperature questions, and the right leg has gram questions. After rolling the dice the player takes the larger of the two dice and moves their token forward and takes a question card from the appropriate stack. If the player answers the question correctly their token remains on that square. If the player is incorrect the player moves backwards the smaller number of spaces. If the player rolls doubles their token is moved forward the total of the two dice, and moves backwards the distance indicated on one die in the case of an incorrect answer. If the player lands on a square the same colour as their token, a chance card is drawn. On some spaces an exam card is drawn. A player cannot move again until an exam question is answered correctly. The first player to travel the board wins.

Each card contains two wheels and a target number. Player must pick the wheel that can make the target number. You can add and subtract only. Use all the numbers on each wheel, but use each number only once. Only one wheel works on each card. Each card is worth 1 to 3 points depending on difficulty. The first player to make the target number wins the card. Player with the most cards wins.

Game uses double nine dominoes and has an electronic Chicken Coop hub. Players start with 7, 9, or 11 dominoes depending on the number playing. The first player who has a double nine plays it in the center hub, and the next six dominoes fill in the spaces around the hub to form the chicken legs (if a player cannot match a nine, they draw and play or pass). After that, players match domino ends until a double is played.

When a double is played, the player presses the hub and normal play is suspended until three chicken "toes" are played. The next three dominoes must match the double and are played under the double, one angled to the left, one in the center and one angled to the right (to form the chicken foot). Players who cannot match can draw and play the match, or they must pass. Play continues until the three toes are completed and normal play resumes either on the chicken toes or any of the chicken legs.

Play ends when a player plays their last domino or the game is blocked (because no plays can be made and the "chicken yard" (spare dominoes) is exhausted. The player who gets rid of their dominoes scores 0. The other players count their pips on their remaining dominoes to get their score. A new round then begins. After 10 rounds, player with the lowest score wins.

A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by bringing together the largest number of periods in the history of France and most of the possible themes of each period.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties.

A Mille Bornes variant with animals in much the same way as its predecessor. Here are ranging animals instead of kilometers!

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties.

A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by collecting the most inventions possible.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties

A Mille Bornes variant in which players must form the sentences with the words on the cards.

The goal is to make sentences with these words. Since we Dujardin, add a few cards of attack and defense. The fire becomes red misspelling, and the green light a dictionary.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties

A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by just replacing the miles by sports, by the lights of the pitfalls and "Long live the Olympics!"

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties.

A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by exposing the maximum cards in as many rounds as possible (there are 12 series: the beginnings, the Patriarchs, Moses, To the promised land, the time of the Kingdom, the time exile, renewal, a new prophet, Jesus' encounters, the messages of Jesus, the passion, the early Christians). Each set contains 6 cards.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties.

A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by exposing the maximum cards in as many rounds as possible (there are 11 series: mushrooms, flowers, evergreens, deciduous trees, shrubs and fruit trees, herbs and spices, exotic plants, plants water, industrial plants, poisonous plants, medicinal plants).

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties

name.value: Mon premier 1000 Bornes: En Route pour l'école

item.description:
"My first Mille Bornes" in English
Multiple rules for different ages.

A simple scenario speaks to all children the road to school!
The whole family moves the car to go from home to school. But beware, you must arrive before the school principal, if not the school doors will close before you even have time to enter the yard!
Game introduces for children the world of the road: signs, traffic lights etc.

The game of Bescherelle is a game designed for fun around the traps and conjugations of the French language.

TO goal is to conjugate a verb or answer a question in French.
Players may get magical potions to transform into superheroes and defence against attacks from your opponents!

Award-winning and recommended by the Ministry of Culture and Communication of France.

A kind of new version of Game of Goose with the theme of 
P.A.F. is (French Audiovisual Landscape)

On the squares with usual pitfalls, you will pass small tests and answer the questions.

Otherwise, the rules of the Game of the Goose are unchanged.

The game includes 5000 questions on French/foreign literature and the French language. It plays like 'snake and ladders', without shortcuts, though.

The board consists of several squares with different topics like: works, authors, expression, citations, parenthesis etc.
Also some special square like:

 Bomb Box: Opponents choose the theme. If the player answers correctly, he continues, otherwise it returns to the starting point.
 Boom Box: The player chooses the theme. If he answers correctly, he continues, otherwise it returns to the starting point.
 Box blank page: Player advances with as many questions indicated on card if he answered said questions correctly.




The winner is the first to be arriving on the "Red and Black" final square and who has also responded right to three questions from a single trivia card.

item.description:
The object of the game is to be the first player or the first team to make a word of at least four letters from the letters earned during the tests.

Playing the game:
The player whose turn it is spins the arrow on the wheel, he draws a card corresponding to the area where the arrow has stopped. He reads the instruction corresponding to its level (aloud or in his head by category). Then he turns the hourglass and following the instructions. It shall reply orally.
Player must find words, rimes, make mimes, solve riddels etc.
If he wins his race, he draws a letter in the bag and the wheel goes to the next player. Otherwise, it passes the wheel to his left to draw no letter in the bag. 
The first player to find the correct answer earns a letter also.

The game ends when one player has formed a word
of at least 4 letters.

Players are journalists and write a newspaper

By answering questions correctly, player draws a cards in the pocket to fill the place on his newspaper. The first player to have completed his newspaper is the winner.

Using the plate divided into several zones, you spin the arrow, and you pull the card corresponding to the area where the arrow is stopped.

There are several type of cards:
- INTERVIEW is a collective issue, the first to answer draws a card from the pouch.
- INTERVIEW PHOTO is a collective issue, but the question is about the photo visible to all players. The first to answer draws a card from the pouch.
- EXPERT is an individual matter. The player whose turn is must answer and draws a card in the pouch for good responders.
- OPPORTUNITY allows to draw a card from the pocket, without having to answer a question.
- BAD LUCK forced the player to deliver one of his cards in the pocket.
- SCOOP is to get a card in an opponent's cards.
- INTERNET cards are optional, as they require an internet connection, to monitor response. If used, they are incorporated in the stack of cards interview.

There are many details on the game boards.
Players spin the spinner and the arrow show tells you what to look for: a character with glasses, a striped object, (the back) is something that can run, is something that can be eaten etc.
Player who first find it scores a point.

Player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

Though the real history of how the Old World powers spread their influence and came to dominate the USA will never be known, American Illuminati gives you the opportunity to demonstrate how, as the leader of one of these old world dynasties, you would have accomplished the feat.

You will become the leader of an ancient Illuminati faction. Your objective is to infiltrate agents into the newly forming United States in order to exert control over the state governments. The more states you control, the greater your power in the federal government. The more control you have in the federal government the more power you have to dominate the world.

AI is a Euro-style board game that plays equally well with 2, 3 or 4 players. The mechanics are simple enough that you can teach most anyone to play, though strategic players are much more likely to win.

Each player is attempting to place agents into the newly forming USA. The more states your faction controls during the four major turning points in 19th century US history, the more conspiracy cards you will draw. Conspiracy cards can be used to gain advantages during the game but are also how you win the game.The Conspiracy Deck mimics a standard deck of playing cards though all the suites are different to fit the Illuminati theme. Throughout the game you are secretly attempting to form the best Poker hand (what's more American than Poker?) with your Conspiracy Cards while playing your Action Cards to maximum advantage.

A recreation of Australian Rules Football using a Tiddlywink mechanic. Players assume the role of the 18th player and move the football to images of the 17 other players on the board. The player retains possession as long as the football is "kicked" to an image of their player who is deemed to have caught or "marked" the ball. If the football falls on the picture of an opposing player or in an open field, the opponent takes control of the ball. Wooden goalposts at each end signify the goalposts and a player can either secure a goal (6 points) or behind (1 point), depending on the accuracy of their aim.

The football has a red and blue side, and if the ball goes off the board ("out of bounds"), it is flipped and whatever colour lands face-up gains possession. When a football equally sits on a red and blue player, the colour that is face-up determines which player has possession. Flipping is also used to determine who kicks the ball first at the commencement of the game or after a goal is scored.

The winner can be determined by the first to reach a pre-determined number of points, or using an elapsed amount of time.

The game first came out during the late 1960s.

Magnetic game in which the purpose is to obtain a capital superior to that of the opponents by extracting the most amount of oil.

Players are represented by 4 Disney characters who try to get rich in this Monopoly style game with a cute oil rig miniature which moves due to a magnet secretly located under the board whenever the players choose to dig for oil in the right spot.

Contents: Board with a trigger tied to 3 magnets located underneath, 4 Disney characters, banknotes, 8 building concession cards, 36 right to drill cards, oil deposits plastic pawns in 2 colors, magnetic oil rig miniature, 2 dice, rules.

item.description:
An old, eccentric archeologist has died and his private collection, rich with a variety of artifacts of various types from various Cultures and Eras, is being auctioned off. These artifacts have not yet been assessed, but as a museum curator, you don't want to wait for that - you do your own research and armed with partial information, you bid based on what you think the item's value might be. Once all bids are in, the artifacts will be assessed, and any bid that's higher than the actual value will not be approved by your board of directors! So for each artifact, the highest bid that is not greater than the actual value will win the auction!

Exhibit is a set collection game with an unusual auction mechanism which is akin to multiple simultaneous games of Liar's Dice.

A cooperative deck building game of heroism.

You won't see Crime City on any map, but that's how people have come to know your hometown. Sadists, Anarchists, the Mafia, each carving out portions of the city they call their own. Hundreds of innocent bystanders caught up every day in their turf wars, or held under their oppressive thumbs. Precious few have the time, the money, the guts, or the wherewithal to do anything about it. You're one of those few... of course it means you'll have to give up that happy home life, or that cushy job. The paper paints vigilantism in a negative light - you'd be viewed by the community as a monster. But your city bleeds... the city bleeds and it calls your name. Will you answer?

You're a vigilante hero, one of the few in Crime City who have come together to put an end to the reign of terror the city's been trapped under. Banding together, you'll fight through a swath of henchmen in order to find and defeat several Arch Villains. But as you get stronger as a hero, you'll have to neglect some parts of your Alter Ego life - your family, your job, and the community.

Each turn you'll play a certain number of cards, and each turn you'll add 1 new card to your deck. Job, Community, and Family cards give you benefits, but in order to fight crime you'll need to play Hero cards instead. As the game goes on, which aspect of your Alter Ego life will you neglect?

While Alter Ego is a cooperative game, there may be a competitive aspect (or mode) as well. In addition to defeating Arch Villains, each player has their own private Nemesis which they need to defeat in order to win the game.

Players race to complete inventions by drafting dice in real time. Build your inventions by grabbing the correct dice... you can draft dice for later by placing it in your scrapyard, but it's not as efficient that way.

Dice Works is a real-time dice drafting game. A number of dice are rolled into the center of the table, and players grab them - one at a time, using only 1 hand - and place them on their player board in an effort to fill up the boxes with the correct assortment of colors. A round ends when all of the dice have been drafted, and players advance their workers into boxes that have been completed.

Players can 'scrap' multiple dice of a single color to create any die they want of that color. The further your workers are advanced, the more efficiently you can scrap.

The winner is the first player to get a worker to the top of 1 (2 on the advanced board) column, finishing an invention!

This game might turn into a spinoff using the dice from Tasty Minstrel Games' Martian Dice game.

Legacy: Gears of Time is a strategic card game, mechanically rooted in its time travel theme. Players each play cards from their own hand, draw from a central draw pile, move and play technologies on a single timeline, while placing their influence cubes on existing technologies.

Legacy is played on a timeline that grows at the end of each of 4 rounds. Players take turns during a round consisting of 3 actions each. During each turn, you may travel back in time, play a technology card from your hand, influence an existing technology, or draw two cards (keeping only one).

As you travel back in time, Technologies are played from your hand by paying their discard cost. Any technologies you play generate influence for you automatically.

Having more influence than your opponents is the key to claiming rewards for a technology! At the end of each round, rewards are given for each technology and its dependencies. One Influence cube from each technology will come off at the end of each round, forming your influence pool to be used in future rounds to influence existing technologies. Keep in mind, a technology is only considered successful if all of its dependencies exist previously on the timeline.

Since there are several copies of each technology, you may be able to preempt and eliminate an existing copy by playing yours earlier in the timeline! Be sure there is room for your new technology, though; each time-frame has a capacity equal to it's distance from the present.

There are also a few rare but powerful Fate cards, each allowing you to break the rules in interesting ways. Fate cards have no discard cost and don't require an action to be played.

By strategically influencing existing technologies, adapting to your opponents actions, and carefully choosing when to go further back in time, you will find yourself victorious over your rivals! History remains intact until the Ancient Machine demands you return to the past to rebuild history, and your Legacy, once more.

Summary:

 4 Rounds
 4 Turns per Round
 3 Actions per Turn (any mix of the following):
 Travel back in Time
 Play a Technology card
 Influence an existing Technology
 Draw two cards (keep one)

item.description:
Paiko is a one-on-one turn based strategy game optimized to cater to intuitive players.

The board and tiles have a Japanese block art aesthetic, which has been cast into black and white for the convenience of print and play. Everything needed to play is provided on our website.

In Paiko, your main objective is to spread out your tiles and block off your opponent's -- capturing your opponent's tiles is a pleasant secondary objective.

You win Paiko by getting 10 points, and you amass points by positioning your tiles in aggressive places on the board. You gain:
0 points for tiles in the safety of your own homeground
1 point for tiles in the even-footed middle ground
2 points for tiles in your opponent's homeground.

On your turn, you can choose to do one of three things: place a tile on the board, move a tile already on the board, or draw 3 more tiles of your choosing. You start the game with a hand of 8 tiles (if white), or 10 tiles (if black). Because Paiko has 8 kinds of tiles, much strategy is involved in choosing your starting hand, and choosing when to spend time building your hand by drawing tiles.

item.description:
The mythical realm of Hyperborea was ruled by an ancient civilization that used magical crystals as their main source of energy. With time, the Hyperboreans became greedy, and their search for power in the deep made the crystals unstable, causing earthquakes, mutations, droughts and floods. Hyperboreans just dug deeper, and only a few wise mages, foreseeing the inevitable, built an unbreakable magical barrier. When the unharnessed magical energy was unleashed from the deep, the Hyperborean civilization was destroyed in a single day, only the magical barrier preventing the disappearance of life from the whole land. The survivors living in the small outposts outside Hyperborea were now sealed out by the barrier. The knowledge of crystals was declared forbidden it was because too dangerous, or simply forgotten.

Over centuries, six rival realms were born from the ashes of the Hyperborean civilization: the militarist Red Duchy; the Emerald Kingdom and its death-delivering archers; the Purple Matriarchy fanatically worshipping the goddess of life; the skilled diplomats and merchants of the Golden Barony; the Coral Throne with its efficiently organized society and finally the secluded and enigmatic Celestial Reign.

The fragile peace between the different realms was not intended to last. One day, the magical barrier suddenly collapsed. A whole new land stood in front of the six kingdoms, still haunted by the old Hyperboreans turned into harmless but ominous ghosts, full of ruins to discover and cities to explore. Each realm is now sending its best warriors and explorers to Hyperborea in order to achieve dominance over their rivals, but which will prevail? Brutal strength or deep understanding of science? The discovery of valuable artifacts in the lost ruins or the retaking of long, lost cities? Only you, as the leader of one of the factions, can lead your people to the ultimate dominance over Hyperborea!

Set in a mythical land of the same name, Hyperborea is a light civilization game for 2 to 6 players that takes 20-25 minutes per player. The game begins at the time when the magic barrier protecting access to the mythical continent of Hyperborea suddenly falls.

Each player takes the role of the leader of a small kingdom situated just outside the now open to be conquered and explored land. Her kingdom has limited knowledge of housing, trade, movement, warfare, research, and growth, but new and exciting powers are hidden in Hyperborea. During the game, this kingdom will grow in numbers and raise armies, extend its territory, explore and conquer, learn new technologies, etc...

The game's main mechanism, which can be described as "bag-building", involves you building a pool of "civilicubes". Each cube represents specializations for your kingdom: war, trade, movement, building, knowledge, growth. Grey cubes represent corruption and waste, and players will acquire them by developing new technologies. (Power corrupts by its own definition, and the more complex a society becomes, the more waste it generates.) Each turn, players draw three random cubes from their bags, then use them to activate knowledge (technologies) they own.

item.description: Edition Wars is a fun-filled, tongue-in-check standalone strategy card game for 3-5 players in which you become a Gamemaster slavishly devoted to your edition of the game! In the effort to champion your edition, you will compete to be the first to assemble a complete group of six Gamers. But this simple task is complicated by the fact that the other Gamemasters are trying to steal your Gamers out from under you! You can respond in kind, defend your existing Gamers with the standard attacks of Snark, Blog, and Merch; as well as equip yourself with special gear and toss about instant critical effects, all of which will aid you on your epic quest to edition supremacy! Let the Edition Wars begin...

Game description from the publisher:

In Empire Express, designed to be an easy-to-play introduction to the Empire Builder series of games, players create competing railroad empires by drawing railroad tracks with crayons upon an erasable board. You win if you utilize your network of rail lines to acquire and deliver goods efficiently to accumulate the largest personal fortune!

The base game provides pre-programmed routes on a board depicting a north-eastern portion of the U.S. with demand cards providing players with an easy way to learn the system through play. Players start with the bare bones of a railroad: an empty train and track connecting some cities. Each turn you and your fellow players take turns building track, operating trains, and delivering loads. The bank will pay you for each delivered load.

With the starting route guided by the board, only two loads per card, and a visual pick-up and delivery guide on every card, the learning curve is greatly shortened.

item.description:
Object of the game is to build his own house by answering the questions for rooms.

Playing the game
Using the dice, each player goes through the corridors of the house.
In choosing his route, he stops at:
- A room: In answering the corresponding question, he wins the card with the room to place it on his house.
- A box 'Forum': He asks the room of their choice to other players and hope they do not know the answer!
- A box 'Mission': He draws a card and runs Mission
- A box 'Bingo': He went into the room of his choice. If he answers the question, he won three-piece card, otherwise he loses 2!
- A secret passage. It uses this shortcut to quickly move from one floor to another house.

Who builds up his house first wins the game.

An educational game about the WTO and how global economy is working. The two ressources chosen here as examples are cotton and coffee. The players play different countries (Vietnam / Kamerun / USA / EU)with different starting conditions. They invest money ("oro") into their own economic engine (and organize their domestic economy) and buy and sell the products on the global market. After two rounds (each containing 5 phases), there is a "minister`s conference", where players discuss and negotiate about different game rules, that will be valid until the next conference.
There are also event cards and negative reactions of the people like "strike", when the domestic economy is not organized well.
Winner of the game is NOT the one with the most money in absolute terms, but who has best developed his country relatively to the starting conditions.
The game was designed by a young woman as her "high school diploma / exam thesis" in Switzerland and was further developed and published by the "EvB" (Erklärung von Bern / Bern Declaration) and distributed by Murmel Spielwerkstatt.

A "race game" placed in the ancient Roman Empire. Each player leads an expedition along the "Amber Road" to gain worthy resources along the travel.

Moving along the Road consumes resources such as water, food, etc. The first thing an expedition needs to do is fill up its supplies. While still in the starting area, a player may take up to four resource tokens and/or coins; he may stay as long in this starting area and take resources as he wants. When a player thinks he has enough for the journey, he takes off.
In a turn, a player has three options: spend two tokens and move one step for each ox you have; move one step without spending tokens; or remain where he is.
If a player moves to a new mapboard, he has to roll the stick beforehand to see which board is placed. After this each player has the option to place a village marker.
On each map section the terrain changes; on a number of special places a player may perform different useful tasks, such as refilling his supply of water, food or acquire an ox.

Villages are useful to buy supplies. Markers that show the 'pax' side consider the village to be friendly, however, when the village is hostile, it attacks the expedition. All oxes and scout then are placed in the bag together with three neutral green tokens. Two tokens drawn from the bag are considered lost.
If the village is friendly, the stick is rolled. The dots shown is the number of resource tokens a player gets for each silver coin in this village.
When the first player reaches the end of the road by exact count, he wins.

Dirigibles of Doom is a beer'n'pretzels type game that allows players to duel it out ... very slowly ... in the skies! The game takes a little planning as both momentum and latency of response are key parts of the mechanic. Too aggressive and a midair collision will wipe out you and your enemy. Too conservative and you are a sitting duck. Blimp. Whatever.

These book contains:

Six pages of rules, resplendent with diagrams
Seven scenarios for head to head, multiplayer, and tournament play
Simple snip-n-flip models for blimps, überblimps, hot air baloons and a dragon ... aw, man, how did That get in there?
Terrain flats, so you can have citites to destroy with your dirigibles
Maneuver cards, formatted to print right out on a standard 10 business card sheet
Suggestions for in-game onomatopoeia!

Stacket! is a game of placing uniquely shaped wooden pieces in an ever increasing tower. Players seek to keep the tower stable after adding a piece while creating ever more difficult challenges for the next player to do the same.

The basic set contains 1 base (starting) piece, 24 additional wooden pieces and a rules sheet in a convenient carrying case.

Stacket! shares a number of mechanics with other block-stacking games such as Bausack, Animal Upon Animal, Blockhead! and Jenga. It is distinct from these other games insofar as each piece placement much touch the previous piece and there is no piece duplication in the common pool. As a result, Stacket! forces players to interact directly on the structure itself and it allows players to use position as well as orientation and weight as a constrain on their opponent's future choices. The dynamics of gameplay which arise from these unique features make it likely that Stacket! will appeal to an audience that is slightly more aggressive and directly competitive. But like each of the other games in the genre, it appeals to any audience that enjoys creative challenges balancing blocks with a degree of strategy.

Optional rules for Stacket! allow players to score points based upon how many existing pieces a new pieces touches when it is placed. Stacket! also has a rules variant for multi-set competition.

item.description:
Ouroboros is an abstract strategy game for 2-4 players, best with 2 players. Players start with no discs, and gain discs from other players during gameplay.

Ouroboros is played on a 6x6 grid filled with four-colors of randomly placed discs. On each player's turn, they do one of three things:
1) Choose a square with a disc in it to place a stone there, taking the disc from that square and giving away the discs orthogonally or diagonally adjacent, OR
2) Remove two stones from the board matching a pattern and discard many discs in specific amounts, OR
3) Discard one disc.

The winner is the first person to get back to zero discs (after the first turn).

item.description:
In Flag Frenzy!, players try to match flags on cards in their hands with flags on the table, emptying their personal card deck before anyone else can.

Flag Frenzy! consists of 49 flag cards and 8 continent cards (two each of Europe, Africa, Asia and the Americas); each flag card shows eight flags, and any two flag cards have exactly one flag in common, similar to the cards in Catch the Match and Spot It!

Game play differs from those titles, however, as two cards are placed face-up on the table at the start of play while the remainder of the deck is distributed evenly among the players. All players take two cards in hand, then everyone simultaneously tries to play onto the face-up cards by spotting the matching flag and giving its country's name when playing the card. With a continent card, the player has to name a flag on the continent being played.

After playing one or two cards, the player refills her hand. The first player to play all of the cards in her deck wins.

1814: Napoleon Buttonaparte and General Ludwig Von York Buttonburg wage a war without mercy, and a new battle is about to begin. The armies are deployed, awaiting orders to move, and in both headquarters the same speech is being presented: "For you, Buttons, the goal is clear: End up on top!" Soon the battle will commence, with each general trying to use the available spies as well as he possibly can to dominate the final battlefield.

As you might guess from the punny names, Button Up! is a non-serious look at combat during war – so non-serious, mind you, that the pieces are buttons, none of which are eliminated due to sucking chest wounds during play. In fact, Button Up! is an abstract game in which players try to manipulate the button troops to score more points than the opponent.

To set up each round of the game, randomly arrange nine buttons in a circle: three red for Buttonaparte, three black for Von York Buttonburg, and three neutral white spies. On a turn, the active player takes one stack that contains a spy, then distributes that stack clockwise one button at a time, with the buttons coming off the bottom of the stack as they're placed. Thus, the first move is a single white button being placed on its neighbor to the left; if that stack is moved on the second turn, the bottom button is placed on its left neighbor, then the white button on top placed to the left of that. If the last button placed matches color with the button it covers, the player who moved it takes another turn. (This doesn't apply if the stack being moved contains more buttons than remaining stacks; in this case, the final buttons are placed on the last stack without rearranging their order.)

When only one stack remains, the round ends. Each button has strength equal to its height in the stack; players sum their strength, and the player with the most strength earns points equal to the difference between the two sums. If one player now has 15 or more points, he wins; if not, shuffle the buttons and start another round with the player who has the fewest points going first.

name.value: La Jeu de la guerre des mots

item.description:
Players form the words on the Scrabble-like game board and try to lead the word path to the central cross of the board.

Players start from their own corners.
In his turn player must use the last letter of the word already on the board and forms the new word starting with this letter.
There are also possibilities to capture opponents' letters.

The player who succeeds first to reach to the central cross, thanks to the progress of his words must forms a last word and wins the game.

Objective: be the first ending on space 43
 - moving by turn -
simple 'Roll & Move' game - roll the die, move & follow instructions printed on cover inside

remarks:
belongs to series: "Scholz' künstlerische Spiele";
game should be published during 1920's
title differs in spelling: 'Schwarzwaldreise' (rules) versus 'Schwarzwald=Reise' (cover)
meeples: pewter figures

Each player has 6 pieces. Two value 1, two value 2 & two value 3.
They place 1 of these in each of the six sports (Running, Swimming, Javelin, Pole Vault, Rowing & Show Jumping).
A die (D3) is rolled & multiplied by the value of the piece to determine how far or high they have managed. This is repeated until the event is complete & Gold, Silver & Bronze are awarded appropriately. Some events may require particular values to be attained in order to continue.
Once all 6 events are complete, points for the medals are added up to decide the winner.

name.value: Mario Party: The Real Life Game

item.description:
Mario Party RLG (the Real Life Game) is a tabletop meta-game inspired by the Mario Party video game franchise. Gameplay is nearly identical to that found in the Mario Party video games, with your personal collection of regular board games replacing the mini-games seen in the video games.

Players roll dice to advance around the board, collecting items, coins and Stars, while trying to avoid Bowser. The player to collect the most Stars is the winner.

This is a free Print-and-Play game.

name.value: Wings of Glory: WW1 Rules and Accessories Pack
Wings of Glory: Pack de règles et d'accessoires WW1
WW1 Wings of Glory: Regel- und Zubehör-Pack

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Wings of Glory is a game system that allows players to recreate aerial combat during World War I and II, using cards and miniatures to represent the airplanes and their maneuvers. In Wings of Glory players will control one or more airplanes, taking to the skies to engage their opponents in aerial duels, or trying to accomplish a specific mission, such as recon, escort, or bombing.

The Wings of Glory: WW1 Rules and Accessories Pack is a complete game system that includes all the rules and accessories necessary to play the WW1 version of the game system. Players will find the core WW1 rules system presented in a beautiful forty-page color booklet with Basic, Standard, Advanced, and a wealth of Optional rules. Also included are all the rules and counters necessary to use special models (such as multi-engine bombers and balloons) and special weapons (anti-aircraft, rockets and incendiary bullets).

The pack also features four decks of Damage Cards (A, B, C, D); Target, Trench, Machine Gun, Anti Aircraft Guns and Bomb cards; four airplane consoles; two rulers; and counters.

Airplane miniatures are not included; the pack must be combined with two or more WW1 Airplane Packs or Special Packs (each featuring a miniature and its maneuver deck), or with a WW1 Duel Pack.

item.description:
Joomba! is a simple party game in which players want to claim as many cards as possible. On a turn you reveal an animal card so that all players can see it; each card features four types of animals on it, with one animal type being present once, another being present twice, another three times, and the final type four times. Competing against everyone else, you must identify the animal that appears on the revealed card a number of times equal to the number on the back of the next card in the deck, then imitate the sound that animal makes.

The rules for Joomba! include three different ways to play.

During the 13th century A.D., the Middle Ages were slowly coming to an end. The Pope and the Empire, the two universal powers that dominated the previous centuries, were breaking apart. Science and technology were beginning to flourish again. Society was rapidly changing, as cities revived and gained autonomy while the feudal system was starting to crumble. 
In Medioevo Universale, you have to lead one of the great kingdoms of those times, while taking control of trade, diplomacy, infrastructure development, scientific progress, and military strategy. Build forts and fortifications, bring war to your enemies, conquer new lands, discover new technologies, expand your commerce, repel the barbarians on the frontiers, recruit armies and fleets, forge alliances, and defeat your opponents in battle!

Medioevo Universale is a game full of components (more than 1700!) with many aspects to manage, deep interactions with other players, and the ability to give you an immersive experience in the medieval era.

In addition of the normal game rules, the box contains also the original prototype rulebook of Nicola Iannone and the elements to play his experimental game version.

item.description:
Players are divided into teams. The "leaders" of each team are made aware of five words to guess in less than a minute bidding and who will use the fewest words to discover them. If the winner succeeds, his team won the map.

Not very original, but with a neat material, which allows you to play great assemblies.

Six Guns and Zombies is board game that has been in the works for two years. Each player begins the game controlling a cowboy that is pre-generated. The cowboys start the game in the end of a canyon near their home town just after being caught in a flash flood on their way back from a cattle drive. Throughout the canyon they see materials scattered all over and someone remembers the payroll was on the chuck-wagon and probably in one of those piles of rubble. Suddenly the players begin to eye each other suspiciously as each decides they want all the gold for themselves. To make matters worse some of the other members of the cattle drive, the ones that didn't survive are getting up and moving towards the cowboys with a hungry look in their eyes. Most of the cowboys are armed with a six gun, but these zombies are endless and their ammo isn't. Now the cowboys must work together against the army of undead in order to survive, but in the back of each cowboy's mind is the payroll, and the chance that one of their fellow cowboys will turn on them.

The main objective of the game is to escape the canyon alive. However if multiple players escape the canyon then the player with the most gold is declared the winner. For a single player game the player must search all twenty boxes and escape the canyon alive.

Ages: 8+ 
Games will last approximately a half hour to an hour.

A party game where guests are each given a card with 18 pictures on it. The pictures are visual cryptic clues to a foodstuff found in a kitchen. For example, picture number 9 is a man cutting wood for logs and the answer is Chops. There are 18 such clues to solve and the first to hand in a completely correct card, wins.

This is one of the publisher's range entitled Can You Solve?
Quickly finds the letters forming the word and press the buzzer to win the card. The first to win 10 cards wins.

link.value: Petit Folimots: Le Corps Humain et les Vêtements
Petit Folimots: Les Fruits, Legumes et Aliments

name.value: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
Agricola: Die Bauern und das liebe Vieh
Agricola: Tutte le Creature Grandi e Piccole

item.description:
Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small is a new take on Uwe Rosenberg's Agricola designed for exactly two players and focused only on the animal husbandry aspect of that game. So long plows and veggies!

In Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small, you become an animal breeder of horses, cows, sheep and pigs and try to make the most of your pastures. Players start with a 3x2 game board that can be expanded during play to give more room for players to grow and animals to run free. Sixteen possible actions are available for players to take, with each player taking three actions total in each of the eight rounds.

The player who amasses the most victory points through enclosing space with fences and acquiring the largest number and variety of animals and victory point-generating buildings will be the winner.

Four Standard Buildings and 4 special buildings are available in the base game. These buildings each provide unique special abilities during play and/or VP at game end. Balancing the tension between building infrastructure (fenced pastures and buildings) and acquiring animals (the single biggest source of end-game scoring) is the key to success!

item.description:
"Join the Earth Heroes on a quest to save the planet!"

It is time for kids to take charge and rescue Earth, which has been ruined by adults. The players are time travelling heroes who must make their way back to Earth from 2259AD and save it from destruction.

The game includes a Team Play option where co-operation is essential, instead of playing as individuals. Game play consists of moving by die roll and following the instructions on the square reached: this could be answering a question from a card, taking a chance card or doing an action card.

There is no waste in the game - the box becomes the board, all the components are made from recycled materials and there is no plastic.

Produced by a team of high school students as part of Young Enterprise.

Playing with four mathematical operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, thanks to two dice.
If the dice show a 6 and a 3, you choose 3 or 6 or 6-3 6x3 or 6:3

In his turn player rolls the dice and choose one of the ADDITION, SUBTRACTION, MULTIPLICATION or DIVISION to gradually bring all his chips from the start square to finish square.

Objective: be the first escaping from the dark castle
 - moving/acting by turn -
simple 'Roll & Move' game
roll the die - 1d6, 1 coloured die, event cards - encounter a ghost, stop at traffic lights, try to find a shortcut, block your opponents...

remarks:
game was developed for >Industrie Und Kunst< by 'Ilse Spiel'

As the leader of your country's federal police, you must stop the infamous Merchant of Death and his international team of Gunrunners as he sells his weapons of destruction in war-torn and drug-ridden countries Will your agents succeed and bring the Merchant of Death to justice?

The object of Gunrunners is to confiscate more crates of weapons than your opponents. Players take turns deploying their agents into one of four locations (Central America, Middle East, North Africa, Southeast Asia). During the game, crates of weapons are delivered to the different locations, so some locations will have more weapons than others. At the end of the game, players confiscate weapons from each of the locations based upon how many agents they deployed to that location. In addition, players may use "Special Operatives" to give them special powers that alter the game play in interesting ways.

item.description:
Overview

Don’t Push Your Luck is an educational game, designed to incite discussion between the players about hemophilia, as well as help youth that live with the condition learn how to make decisions that are in their best interests. The game supports 2-4 players and is played over the course of 45 minutes. The game contains mechanisms that are not normally seen in educational games, and the effect is learning through engagement (fun). It also features attractive youth-friendly graphic design to further increase the accessibility, engagement and desire to play. Don't Push Your Luck combines light strategy of a family Euro with the fun and social exploration of a Party Game.

Just Another Day
Each player in Don’t Push Your Luck takes on the role of a child with hemophilia competing to have the most well balanced lifestyle, while trying to manage the risk they take in their activities. Players will be faced with the constant challenge of balancing of risk vs reward. The game is played over three rounds, each representing one full day.

There is a central board surrounded by 16 activity cards, that are randomly drawn before the beginning of each round. Each activity card represents a specific type of health: mental, social, emotional, and physical. In turn, players go around the board picking up activity cards and placing them in their player area. This represent them performing this activity. For example: on your turn you may choose to take the “hockey” activity card. Hockey provides 2 physical icons on it. These icons are later used to obtain “stars”, at the various “star spaces” around the board. The player with the most “stars” at the end of the game is declared the winner. 
 
Inciting Discussion
Players must be mindful of the activities they choose to participate in during the day, because at the end of every round (3 total), each player tells a story about their day by describing each of the activities they selected. When the storyteller is finished telling describing each of their selected activities, the other players have an opportunity to discuss which of those activities they felt were not in the best interest of the story teller. The storyteller will often be trying to play down the risk of their selected activities, as they will be judged by the other players.

link.value: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

item.description:
A typical roll and move game with a theme of travelling by car through western Europe. Each player draws destination cards and have to travel from Berlin to them and back to Berlin the fastest. There are naturally some special fields along the way; bordercontrols, gas stations and accidents.

This version is Norwegian, with no known publisher, but with production nr 2201 and according to the map and general production has to date from the between the first and second world war. There are references to East Prussia and Jugoslavia on the map as well as country borders that are different than today's.

As game production in Norway was very limited during this period, and the fact that Berlin is the starting and ending point as well as all the countries and cities are named in their national language, one may assume that the game is a localized version of a foreign game.

This game is a merchandising product of the formerly "Dresdner Bank".

Goal of the game is collecting shares, while reducing your cash to 5.000 "Drumbo"´s.

Each player gets an amount of 30.000 (3 or 4 players) or 50.000 (2 players) Drumbos.

The players move forward or backwards on the board and may draw different cards, accordingly the field they end their move. The players need to stop on the field "Bankfiliale" to change cash into shares.

End-Scoring:
In the order of arrival at the goal, the players multiply their shares with 4 (first player), 3 (second player), 2 (third player). The player with the highest amount of shares wins.

Party game that tests the players' knowledge of motor car manufacturers.

Each player is given a card with 26 clues to the name of a motor car. For example;
Clue 1: A Wanderer = Rover
Clue 13: A Famous General = Wolseley

There is one cryptic clue;
A Beheaded Duck, which is meant be a (M)allard!

They are generally British cars as you might expect in a British game but two relate to American cars. I don't think many Brits would know Dodge or Plymouth.

When a guest has finished all 18 solutions, their card is handed to the host. The first to do so, with 18 correct answers, wins.

Note that this box is much larger than any other party games that I have from this era. It is also bright and colourful, another trait often missing from similar games. Unfortunately, the company must have decided that this presentation was too expensive because they soon reverted to the more traditional sized and look of most party games by their competitors.

Party game that tests the guests' knowledge of car parts.

Each player receives a card with 19 clues to the name of a car part. The clues take the form of an anagram with the letters all shuffled around. Example;

TBNOEN = Bonnet (that is the Hood for American readers)
GNANDRUNOBSIR = Running Boards (that is a very nostalgic feature of a car, I think).

The guest who first hands in a correct card, wins.

Party game with 26 unusual clues to names of 26 things, each one beginning with a different letter of the alphabet, starting with A and ending with Z.

The clues are given as part of a verse. For example;

"A" is a Continent - enormously big
"B" stands for part of the flesh of a pig
"C" is a film-star, you know his face
"D" stands for a very well-known horse race
etc.

The answers to the above are;
America
Bacon
Charlie Chaplin
Derby

The first to hand in a card with 26 correct answers, wins.

Party game, unusually published as a pad with removable sheets.

On this sheet are clues to two words. However there ia third word, which is the correct answer to the clue. By this I mean, each word, beheaded (i.e. with the first letter knocked off), gives another word, and this beheaded again, gives a third word. Clues to the first word and the last word are given. The players must work out the middle word. An example;

From a shelter for horses to skilful;
First word = Stable
Last word = Able
So the middle word is Table and that is the answer a player must find to answer it correctly.

The first guest to hand in a sheet with 16 correct answers, wins.

Party game that tests players' knowledge of Geography.

Each guest is given a sheet of 16 clues to a territory in Europe, Asia, Africa or South America. I don't know why North America was left out, but it was. The clues take the form of three six letter words. Any two consecutive letters within each word will combine to form a six letter word answer. Example of a North American clue had North America been included;

SCARED
ANNALS
DANGER
The answer is CA NA DA so the answer is Canada

The first player to hand in 16 correct answers, wins.

Party game for wordsmiths.

Each guest is given a sheet with 16 clues. Each of the clues takes the form of one or two words. The clue contains the name of some vehicle or means of transport with wheels. The letters appear in their right order, but not necessarily consecutively. The number in brackets indicates the number of letters in the word answer. An example;

Revelation (3) = VAN

The first guest to hand in 16 correct answers, wins.

Party game that has correct answers but I expect the wrong answers provide more amusement.

Each guest is given a card that tells the story of a day's outing to a zoo. However the story is punctuated with blank words and the players must hand in a card with all the missing words added correctly. Each missing word is the name of an animal. For example;

"... as slow as a t - " = Tortoise.
That was an easy one. Now try this;
"Is it going to r - ?" = Reindeer (i.e. Rain, Dear)

The first player to hand in a correct card, wins.

One in the "Dainty" series of games.

A party game for wordsmiths.

Each guest is given a card with 24 clues. The answer to each clue is a word ending in 'ster'. For example;

Clue 1. Ogre = Monster
A harder one; Clue 9. Cockney Hawker = Coster

A costermonger was a person who sold things, usually fruit and vegetables, from a handcart in the street. A Cockney is someone traditionally born within the sound of Bow Bells, situated in the East End of London. However the name is often given to a Londoner born and bred anywhere in London.

The first guest to hand in their card with 24 correct answers, wins.

One of the games in the Dainty Series by this publisher.

Similar mechanism as in Folix but there is a addition instead of multiplication.

Players turn the cards face up, and find the two pawns whose product is equal to the number upon the card. The colors upon the card and pawns must also fit, which makes easy to check at a glance that the pair is correct. Some pawns do not bear numbers, but lead to special actions such as turn the board, play again, lose pawns. First to have 20 pawns wins the game.

A party game for doctors (!) perhaps.

Each guest is given a card with 25 clues to which the answer is a part of the body. An example:

Clue 22. The law is credited with having a long one = Arm (as in the long arm of the law)

The first guest to hand in a card with 25 correct answers, wins.

One game in the Dainty Series of games by this publisher.

Roll the dice and if one dice show the image on the card, write it quickly with your letters, in the time shown on the second dice. Pressing the buzzer and won the card!

Can be used as an educational tool as well that as a game of speed and reflexes.
Learning mode for small, mode for the biggest challenge.

Player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner

Each player has a hand of 6 cards and his turn, he will write his cards with a 'PRIMO'-word. But also some cards has special abilities: 'Star' can replace any letter or some cards make coffee break losing a turn to Your opponent.

To win the game, you have to be the first to write 4 'PRIMO' words: 'PRIMO 3' (word of 3 letters), 'PRIMO 4' (word of 4 letters), 'PRIMO 5' (word of 5 letters) and a 'PRIMO 6' (word of 6 letters), in any order.

A party game for children.

Each guest is given a score-card, with 24 clues to different Nursery Rhyme character. The clues take the form of a rhyming couplet. An example;

Clue 2. Who was the girl who once had such a scare,
A big horrid spider, her seat wished to share?
Answer = Miss Muffet

The first child to return a correct score-card, wins.

One game in the Dainty Series by this publisher.

Letter-cards are shuffled and dealt to each participant in one color. Then a word is drawn and all players try to form this word with his letters. First presses the buzzerand earn the card as a point.

Player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Contents:

 1 game board, 
 80 double-sided cards, 
 a buzzer, 
 four batches of 60 letters in color duplex

A hex based gladitorial combat game. You run a school of gladiators in ancient Rome.You can use chits or miniatures. The system of combat favors fast, bloody games instead of complexity and minute detail. It was designed to be familiar to role players and a entry point for casual players to become familiar with historical gaming.

The goal of the game is to win the most money by determining when is the best time to fight or use manipulation to increase your pocket book.

Each player starts with finances predetermined before playing. This amount can be changed each game to allow for shorter or longer campaigns. The players the purchases fighters for their stable, armor and can invest in creating better stats for their fighters. 
 In later editions the rules added a political component for multi-player campaigns.

Objective: collect cards scoring most winning points
 - acting by turn -
active player turns the spinner
1 draw a correspondent card if spinner points on a symbol (8 x 4 cards + 1 devil)
2 if all 4 cards of a chosen symbol are gone ==> take the devil (out of the box or from a player)
3 if devil is yours and pointer ends on devil symbol ==> discard a card (typically with lower value)
4 it all cards are picked game ends at once - winner is player who scored most points 
remarks: published early 1960's

name.value: Moopher's Amazing Journey to the Sea!
Moopher présente le voyage extraordinaire à la mer!

item.description:
The Official Game of the Saskatchewan River Basin!

The story of Moopher begins in a gopher burrow beside a river. One day the curious gopher met a moose. They spent the day together nibbling on plants and sharing stories. The gopher was curious about the mountains the moose talked about and he wanted to go there. The moose said it was too dangerous. The gopher asked why the moose was not afraid. The moose replied that he had antlers to protect him.

That night the gopher dreamed about seeing the mountains. He even dreamed he grew a set of antlers. When he woke up he had an idea. He took the antlers from a plastic deer and taped them to his head. His friend the moose saw him and said "You are the size of a gopher but have antlers like a moose. You must be a Moopher!" Together they traveled to the mountains. One day Moopher met a trout. The trout told Moopher that all rivers run to the sea. When Moopher heard about the sea, he said good-bye to his friends and set off on his amazing journey.

Each player starts on a leaf that marks the headwaters of a river. There are three ways to help Moopher move. Each space on the board is numbered. To move ahead one space, the player must roll the exact number needed on three dice. If one die is the exact number needed, or any of the dice can be added to get the right number, the player moves. The player can also choose to play a memory game with cards or answer a river question. The first player to move their token into Hudson Bay is the winner.

link.value: Partners FOR the Saskatchewan River Basin

item.description:
Objective: be the first to reach the target space (with matching move)
 - moving by turn -
1 players take red route - first round
2 throw the die - ending on a marked space follow instructions printed on cover inside
3 players take black route - second round - same procedure

Objective: be the first reaching target space 'E'
- simple 'Roll & Move' game/ moving by turns -
each player moves his/her meeple according die roll
ending on a numbered space follow instructions of the rule sheet

remarks:
unbalanced events

Syzygy is a tactical boardgame for 2 to 4 players in which your goal is to get three connected planets of the same colour in one straight line, without getting surprised by a Syzygy of your opponent.

In astronomy, a Syzygy is a straight line configuration of three or more celestial bodies in a gravitational system.

Online Play

 Boardspace.net Real time, against humans or robot players

A party game designed to persuade your guests to mingle during the evening.

Each guest either gets a blue or red badge for their lapel. The blue badgesfeature a number. The red badges have a clue to a number. The idea is to find the clue you think that might be the answer to your number, or find the number that you think might be the answer to your clue. The first pair to 'match-up' are the winners (and, I suspect, will get a small gift from the host).

The matching pair are now partners for the evening and must partner each other for things like Novelty dances (such as the Gay Gordons).

A party game intended to make "a tremendously successful party" (so says the publisher).

The host places Key Cards around the house or garden, depending on the venue for the party. For a garden party, it is suggested that you try to place the cards in unusual locations, including 'up a tree'!!

Each guest gets a card that shows, at the top, the name of a house (the British love giving a name to their house). That is their start point. They must find the Key Card with that house on it and that will tell them the name of the next house Key Card they must look for. When you find a house that you need, you must write down the defect of the house. This will prove that you did indeed find the card.

The first player to find all 12 houses required, wins.

Rather hopefully, the publisher says that if you buy extra score cards (called House Agents' Lists) up to 500 people can play! The mind boggles!!

A party game that tests your guests' trivia knowledge.

Each player gets a score-card, to record their answers. On the left of the card their are categories and alongside that there are 5 blank boxes. Between these two things (the category and the answer boxes) is the word 'Swaffield', going from top to bottom. D. E. Swaffield was the founder of the publisher. He designed some of its games and wrote some of the books that it published.

Swaffield has 9 letters in its name and when written vertically, it provides the initial letter required to answer the category correctly. For example:

The first category is 'Names of noted men who have written books' and the first letter is an S (as in Swaffield). The second category is 'Things in or one the sea' and these must begin with W, the second letter of Swaffield. And so on down to the last category called 'Counties in England and Wales' which will need the initial letter of D (the last letter in the word Swaffield).

The object is to write down five things that are indicated by the category and all five must begin with the associated letter. The host should set a time limit and the winner is the guest with the most valid answers.

18 cards are placed around a room where the guests can easily see them. The guests receive a score-card, on which they will write down their answer.

The cards have an illustration which is a kind of illustrated cryptic clue. Under the picture is the item that guests must write down in their related answer. Card examples:

Card 6. A close-up picture of a tree and the subject is 'Find the Misician'. Answer = Bach (suggested by the Bark of the tree)
Card 17. A picture of a Shell oil can and the subject is 'Find the Seagull'. Answer = Petrel (the visual clue is Petrol)

I told you they were cryptic!

The first player to answer all 18 cards correctly, wins.
